body: Closing as no objections were raised and it is addressed with #2086.

It seems like a poorly designed side effect of "unlock diagnostic vm options" that this would automatically activate some performance related options.  That being said, whether we add this in to the default set of options should be based on how reliable those options are.  If we can count on this performance increase regardless of the updates in JVMs that come down the pike, then I am ok with this.

I think you would end up having to add `-XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions` in any case. For example, let's say that you want to use the GHASH Intrinsic (added in https://bugs.openjdk.org/browse/JDK-8073108).

It's not enabled by default:
```
~$ java -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal -version | grep -i GHash
openjdk version "11.0.15" 2022-04-19 LTS
OpenJDK Runtime Environment 18.9 (build 11.0.15+9-LTS)
OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM 18.9 (build 11.0.15+9-LTS, mixed mode, sharing)
```

If you enable just that option, you get the message saying you have to add `-XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions`:
```
~$ java -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal -XX:+UseGHASHIntrinsics -version | grep -i GHash
Error: VM option 'UseGHASHIntrinsics' is diagnostic and must be enabled via -XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions.
Error: The unlock option must precede 'UseGHASHIntrinsics'.
Error: Could not create the Java Virtual Machine.
Error: A fatal exception has occurred. Program will exit.
```

When added:
```
~$ java -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal -XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -XX:+UseGHASHIntrinsics -version | grep -i GHash
     bool UseGHASHIntrinsics                       = true                                   {diagnostic} {command line}
openjdk version "11.0.15" 2022-04-19 LTS
OpenJDK Runtime Environment 18.9 (build 11.0.15+9-LTS)
OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM 18.9 (build 11.0.15+9-LTS, mixed mode, sharing)
```

But also enabled if you don't add `-XX:+UseGHASHIntrinsics` (and it's supported on your platform, etc.):
```
~$ java -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal -XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -version | grep -i GHash
     bool UseGHASHIntrinsics                       = true                                   {diagnostic} {default}
openjdk version "11.0.15" 2022-04-19 LTS
OpenJDK Runtime Environment 18.9 (build 11.0.15+9-LTS)
OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM 18.9 (build 11.0.15+9-LTS, mixed mode, sharing)
```

So, if you add `-XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions` you enable *all* of the "diagnostic" options. If any of them is unreliable, then you will likely have to disable it using `-XX:-<option>`.

You can view the diagnostic parameters, and which one's are enabled on your platform, using the command:
```
java -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal -XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -version | grep diagnostic
```

For Accumulo, I would think that users might want to enable many things for inlining, hashing, compression, and encryption.

If any of these are marked experimental, then I think we should not be enabling them by default.  Would providing an "experimental" config, along side (or enabled from) the standard configuration be a better path?  We could point to these things as you are likely to want, but you should test in your environment, rather than just making them our default - which seems to add weight that we *know* that they are appropriate?

> If any of these are marked experimental

I don't believe these are experimental. There is another option for experimental properties, you can see them with:

```
java -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal -XX:+UnlockExperimentalVMOptions -version | grep experimental
```
Full IT build passed successfully
Well then I have to ask whether there are other options that the UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions does not automatically enable that we may want to use?

Is / was the SunnyDay tag replace or superseded with the the sunny profile? I think the following will run the sunny day marked tests:

```
mvn clean verify -Psunny
```

@ivakegg Next time, please squash the PR commits to merge with a clean history. That's been our routine practice for a long time, with relatively few exceptions. The option in GitHub is called "Squash and Merge". If it's not the default for you in the big green merge button, then you can select it by choosing the arrow next to the merge button.

Repeating my earlier question:

> Also, are you anticipating creating a backport PR for 1.10 after this is merged to 2.1?

> @billoley Thanks. I didn't see the reference to the original issue in the PR description or subject line, so didn't make the connection. I think the original issue sufficiently describes the situation observed in detail. However, it doesn't quite explain the nature of these changes, which we'll need summarized for the squashed git commit when we merge this. If you have a brief summary of the changes being done om the PR, that will allow the reader to connect back to the more detailed description contained in the referenced issue, that would be helpful.

@ivakegg @billoley My comment above seems to have been completely ignored, when I suggested that the commit message need to be improved when this is merged as a squashed commit. None of the 7 commits added a concise description of the changes, and the last commit message did not even follow git log conventions, having a subject line that is long enough to wrap my wide screen. Yet it was merged, as-is, anyway. Please consider reviewing the suggestions in https://cbea.ms/git-commit/ for writing good commit messages.

> Is / was the SunnyDay tag replace or superseded with the the sunny profile? I think the following will run the sunny day marked tests:
> 
> ```
> mvn clean verify -Psunny
> ```

Yea that still works. It has its own profile:
https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/bf9b0f69cf72c854aac2ca12af03f4ec33e5bf04/pom.xml#L1509-L1516

Oddly enough this works by using the failsafe.groups, the same thing that the manual maven command fails on.

> Oddly enough this works by using the failsafe.groups, the same thing that the manual maven command fails on.

Looking closer, I don't think `-Psunny` has been running the tests that we expect it to be running. Matching up the tests that have the `@Tag` (formerly `@Category` in JUnit4) to the tests that are actually run, they are different. I'm not sure where the group of tests `Psunny` runs is coming from but as far as I can tell its the wrong set of tests.
KeywordStartIT has been fixed. The issue was I inadvertently removed the main method from the DumpZookeeper command which is still marked with KeywordExecutable and not part of the Admin command.
Would using stderr at places where we call exit to dump a stack trace be practical - that would eliminate the dependency on an loggers.

After talking offline to @EdColeman I am going to try a different approach of creating a new command called `du_meta` that will be simpler and just do the metadata scan on the client side and not touch the RPC call or the current command. The metadata stores the HDFS file sizes and this seems like a faster option for getting the output by doing the client side scan vs having to send an RPC call. The help for the command can mention the fact that for the most accurate info that a flush/compaction should be run so metadata is updated.

The old command can stay for now and eventually be marked as deprecated and removed if this new one performs better as expected. I also plan to add some flags to support different options such as computing the size of a single Table or all tables in a namespace, etc.
Seems reasonable - can you submit a PR against the main branch?

@EdColeman - new working branch for the client side only version is here if you want to take a look: https://github.com/cshannon/accumulo/commits/accumulo-2820-client

This is by no means finished and still very much a work in progress and I will continue with it later this week, probably Friday. The output still needs work as some stuff is missing and it needs cleaning up and refinement.  I did add a verbose flag to spit out the breakdown when data is shared across tables just like the original command does when using a pattern or namespace. Besides working on code cleanup and fixing up the output (maybe with more flags to do extra things to customize the output) there are still no tests yet since I'm still experimenting so hopefully I can get to that when I am back to working on it at the end of the week so I can get a PR (or at least a draft PR) ready for review.

**Also a note about shared file linking/detection:**

Right now when linking shared files only one scan is done, so like the original command, shared files are only going to be detected if the table provided or looked at is referencing files from another table and doesn't "own" thtem. So lets say you have table1 and table2 is a clone and they share table1's file. If you ran du currently on table1 then there would be no indication that there was a shared file as only files that come back are owned by table 1. but if you ran a du on table2 then the file that comes back points to table1 so you know its shared. If we want to be able to show shared files between tables in any direction and no matter which table you query then we'd need to scan again for tables that match each file. 

With the same example you'd need to scan for table1 and get the list of files back that it owned and then scan again with those files to see if any other tables have a hit to associate it. This is not a problem if we use a pattern (regex) and the pattern matches both tables already as when we scan we hit both tables and know they are associated which is why the output of the command for the original "du" command looks a bit different depending on if you give it a single table or a regex.

I think we are ok with this behavior as the old command works the same way and adding extra scans would add complexity and a performance hit that I don't think is necessary. Ultimately it really depends how you want to define shared. One way to look at it is in the example above table1 is not using shared files from table2 as it owns the files, only table2 has shared files being used from table1.

I did run into an interesting bug. I had the monitor auto-refreshing but none of the drop-downs worked. The buttons themselves worked but that is about it. I think this is because I had the auto-refresh enabled on the monitor before updating to these changes.

So part of the initial failure is the fact the first category that gets run with `mvn verify` (accumulo project) has no tests (sunny or otherwise). I am not sure if the command is enough to have maven skip certain sections or not. 

As it currently stands, just running `mvn clean verify -Psunny` will run all the unit tests but I did get just the sunnyDay tests by running `mvn clean verify -Dtest=foo -Psunny`. Right now that profile doesn't exclude anything which is why it will run everything else beforehand.

I think that can be done. It looks like sync and async logging can be used (ref: https://logging.apache.org/log4j/2.x/manual/async.html). But it looks like that is done per logger. I'd like to be able to configure that all `errors` are logged synchronously.
Someone else reported something similar: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LOG4J2-2267

> I did run into an interesting bug. I had the monitor auto-refreshing but none of the drop-downs worked. The buttons themselves worked but that is about it. I think this is because I had the auto-refresh enabled on the monitor before updating to these changes.

I was not able to get auto-refresh working. Did you have it working after updating to these changes?
Thank you for the reply! I will try to submit a PR today.

It looks like a few other test cases in OpTimerTest could get the same treatment too.

Also, if you are interested in further improving these tests, you could optionally add descriptive messages to the assert statements and assert that the expected message is returned from `assertThrows`.

> I did get just the sunnyDay tests by running `mvn clean verify -Dtest=foo -Psunny`. Right now that profile doesn't exclude anything which is why it will run everything else beforehand.

Good catch. Something must have changed at some point (maybe surefire/junit version update) that changed this behavior. I was able to get just the `@Tag`ed SunnyDay tests to run with the command you mentioned or by adding the following property to the `sunny` profile: `<test>foo</test>`.

I'm not too sure what all we want to have run with the `sunny` profile but running the options above on my machine take about 20 minutes where as before I remember -Psunny taking about 6/7

This also works to run the groups of tagged tests i.e., `mvn clean verify -Dtest=foo -Dfailsafe.groups="<tag name>"`
I think I'll close this ticket since it has been found that running groups of tests via their tag does work. If we want to open a separate ticket/PR to modify the `sunny` profile we can do that.
@milleruntime @ctubbsii - we have two different opinions on this, we could use some other input here to figure out a way forward.

> move the utility to the Admin command like the other PRs otherwise just remove it entirely.

I would prefer this be moved under Admin, like we did with the other utilities. This one seems too specific to make it a high level Keyword.
Seems like a good compromise.

@milleruntime and @dlmarion  - thanks for the feedback, I'll re-work the PR and move it to the Admin command like the others.

Can we go ahead and merge #2881 first? Then I can just update this to fit in in alphabetical order and remove the main method like the others.

```

Is there another dependency that I missed?

@EdColeman agreed. Will these updates be part of the next release of accumulating?? (Like 2.1 or the next version)

When the release from 2.1 is created it will be from the main branch, so yes, once that PR is merged they would be included in the release.  It is likely that another sweep of the dependencies will be done just prior to the release to capture updated versions that might occur between merging the current PR and the when the release is prepared.
@milleruntime - are you okay with this as is, or do you think there should be additional changes?

I was thinking that we would want to set exclude and include properties, the same way that we do in clone configuration, but I am not sure we need to with import table. With the offline option, users can easily configure the table as they see fit before bringing it online and the main goal of the table export/import process is to migrate the config to another table.
The full set of ITs passed (two tests failed on first run with transient errors - succeed on retry.)

> @milleruntime - are you okay with this as is, or do you think there should be additional changes?

Just some javadoc clean up, then it can be merged.

> With the offline option, users can easily configure the table as they see fit before bringing it online and the main goal of the table export/import process is to migrate the config to another table.

Agreed, we can avoid the complexity of adding code to manage properties in the import by simply allowing folks to keep the table offline and making configuration changes before bringing the table online. There is nothing that prevents the folks performing these modifications manually or automating them with code.

I reviewed this as well and it also LGTM. 

This may not be a big deal but my only comment is it would be nice to see a couple tests written for `ConfigRefreshRunnner` to verify the `verifySnapshotVersions()` method does what it is supposed to do after running, either running directly or through an integration test. (Check the cache entries were removed and configs inside ServerConfigurationFactory were cleared, etc). It's possible there are some existing tests that will exercise the change that already exist but I didn't see it with a quick search.

Running it directly would be a little annoying as you would either need to change the scope to package/protected to access it in tests so you could instantiate a new runner and execute `verifySnapshotVersions()` or use reflection.

For an ITest I suppose you could make the refresh interval configurable and set it something to be pretty short (a few seconds maybe) to verify it ran properly and evicted entries.
Tested encryption using Uno and CI.
@DomGarguilo Did you find any sign of improvement with the Apache Commons Unsynchronized classes?

> @DomGarguilo Did you find any sign of improvement with the Apache Commons Unsynchronized classes?

Looking at the result of my benchmarks, it doesn't look like there is any improvement. That being said, I'm not sure how much weight we should give to the results of those benchmarks in terms of how accurately they represent how this would be used in our code. In conclusion - inconclusive :laughing:

> > @DomGarguilo Did you find any sign of improvement with the Apache Commons Unsynchronized classes?
> 
> Looking at the result of my benchmarks, it doesn't look like there is any improvement. That being said, I'm not sure how much weight we should give to the results of those benchmarks in terms of how accurately they represent how this would be used in our code. In conclusion - inconclusive

An inconclusive result, is a fair assessment though. The fact that you weren't able to see any improvements tells me that it is probably not worth the effort to make the change or pursue any further.
I think all the logic is sound for this improvement but there is just some minor cleanup that could be done, most likely due to cherry picking and/or multiple contributors.
I think this field is only used to pass the Row from the MetadataScanner to the Manager when a problem is detected and the TabletGroupWatcher will try to repair the metadata.
Do you think that this change would make things less readable? To me it seems nice to have commas when reading long numbers.
Would surrounding the values in double quotes help - that may make parsing easier and maintain readability?
All ITs are passing.

@EdColeman - Here is the version version of the new command. There could be some more enhancements done either on this PR or a follow on. Some other stuff we could add includes adding pagination to the command output, computing disk usage breakdown by tablets (if you think that's useful but may be too fine grained) and possibly renaming this command to be "du" and renaming the old one to something else.
I'm not really concerned about breaking the fluo-uno build if there is a way to fix it. Downstream projects will have to be updated for changes in Accumulo.
Recent commits have solved my issues so once @DomGarguilo's issues are resolved then this should be good to go. Good work.

I think it would be better to just add an option to the existing `du` command. It shouldn't be too difficult to make the existing command take an option called `-meta` that will perform this scan instead of the legacy one.

This [issue](https://bugs.openjdk.org/browse/JDK-8145348) is where they made all of the instrinsics `diagnostic`. This [issue](https://bugs.openjdk.org/browse/JDK-8153655) notes that they had to update all of the intrinsic tests to add `UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions` to the JVM options as some of the intrinsics moved from `product` (and enabled by default) to `diagnostic`. Follow-on [issue](https://bugs.openjdk.org/browse/JDK-8169585) to update the documentation for instrinsics to note that `UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions` is now required.

@milleruntime The basic question is there value in the current command?  While it is very through in the calculation it is also unusable on large tables.  What information is the current command providing that if it can run, is not provided by this new version?
Isn't this something that should be done in the `/etc/hosts` file?

> Isn't this something that should be done in the `/etc/hosts` file?

I'm not sure I understand how that solves this issue. If you start a server with an ip address (`-a 1.2.3.4` for example) or the `-a` argument is not supplied and the ip address is resolved from the hostname (`1.2.3.4` for example), then the server will bind to ip address `1.2.3.4` *only*.

Edit: It was also put the address `1.2.3.4` in ZooKeeper as the location for that server.

> @milleruntime The basic question is there value in the current command? While it is very through in the calculation it is also unusable on large tables. What information is the current command providing that if it can run, is not provided by this new version?

Yes, the current shell command just calls the Java API. I am suggesting to add an option to improve the current shell command. If there is a problem with the API then we should deprecate it and modify the shell command to call the new scan. There is no need for a new shell command that returns the same information.

If the new command is sufficient - then my position would be to have it named `du` and replace the current command.  If there is a reason to keep the current command, then I'd suggest that it be renamed and deprecated and then eventually removed - otherwise it could be removed / replaced now.

That decision can be made after this code is reviewed.

> > Isn't this something that should be done in the `/etc/hosts` file?
> 
> I'm not sure I understand how that solves this issue. If you start a server with an ip address (`-a 1.2.3.4` for example) or the `-a` argument is not supplied and the ip address is resolved from the hostname (`1.2.3.4` for example), then the server will bind to ip address `1.2.3.4` _only_.
> 
> Edit: It was also put the address `1.2.3.4` in ZooKeeper as the location for that server.

Couldn't you just start the Monitor using `-a 0.0.0.0`? I guess I don't understand what problem this is trying to solve. Can you explain what you mean by "some constraints in containerized environments"?

> If the new command is sufficient - then my position would be to have it named `du` and replace the current command. If there is a reason to keep the current command, then I'd suggest that it be renamed and deprecated and then eventually removed - otherwise it could be removed / replaced now.
> 
> That decision can be made after this code is reviewed.

Since `du` command is unusable on large clusters, we should just make `du` use the new metadata scan by default and add an option like `du -hdfs` to preserve the current technique.

The `-hdfs` option is attractive - but am thinking the specific question should be addressed: what value is provided by the current command that is not addressed with the new approach?

I am concerned that I could be missing the utility of the current approach - are there specific use cases where that approach is necessary? Can they be addressed in another fashion?  This is a general question that should be used to guide how a replacement / improvement is handled.

I am not saying the current approach is unnecessary - I just don't understand the complexity behind it and if that is necessary to provide a command that provides the hdfs space used by a table (or group of tables)

Ok, looking at the code again, I see that I had the order for starting the Jetty web server and the insert of the node into ZK backwards.

If I use `-a 0.0.0.0`, then the web server will bind to `0.0.0.0` and the ZK entry will reflect the hostname's resolved address.
If I use `-a 1.2.3.4`, then the web server will bind to `1.2.3.4` and the ZK entry will be `1.2.3.4`

The latter won't work; the issue I ran into was [this](https://serverfault.com/questions/1057081/why-does-kubectl-port-forward-require-the-destination-service-to-be-bound-to-loc) one. I used `-a 1.2.3.4` when starting the Monitor and both the Jetty web server and ZK address used that address. I could not reach the monitor in this case. 

I still think this property, or one that allows the user to specify the monitor bind address, would be useful. In a situation where you have the Monitor running on a host with multiple NIC's, and you have traffic separated.

My vote would be to make this new command the new `du` command and just remove the old one entirely if the outputs are the same. The only reason to keep the old one would be is if they might differ but I haven't found that to be the case. The metadata always seems to contain the actual file size. Granted my knowledge is still limited as I'm new to this so someone else might have an example of when they differ (just an estimate, etc). If there is a good reason to keep it then I like the idea of making the new version the default and having a flag like `-hdfs` to use the old version.

Confirmed that using `-a 0.0.0.0` does work. ZK contained:
```
get /accumulo/836a122d-320f-47e9-afbb-58aaefd4310c/monitor/http_addr
http://accumulo-monitor-744588d856-6dh7b:9995/
```

So, it's not using the IP address of the hostname, it's using the hostname.
I'm closing this PR. Setting the address for the Monitor process to 0.0.0.0 resolves this issue.
It looks like I can change `NUM_TSERVERS=1` to `export NUM_TSERVERS=${NUM_TSERVERS:=1}`. If NUM_TSERVERS is already defined in the environment, then it will use that, else default to 1.

The file sizes stored in the metadata table are estimates.  I see 2 options:

1. Create a new option to the `du` command to call the new API method (something like `du -meta` or `du -estimate`)
2. Change the behavior of `DUCommand` to make it always scan the metadata. If we do this, we should add an option to call the current `getDiskUsage()` API (something like `du -hdfs`) and document in the release notes.

> The file sizes stored in the metadata table are estimates. I see 2 options:
> 
> 1. Create a new option to the `du` command to call the new API method (something like `du -meta` or `du -estimate`)
> 2. Change the behavior of `DUCommand` to make it always scan the metadata. If we do this, we should add an option to call the current `getDiskUsage()` API (something like `du -hdfs`) and document in the release notes.

Option number 2 seems like the best option to me. One thing would be is if we combine the two commands then i'd have to update the old command as well to output in the new format. We don't have to do that but the old command doesn't do the calculation total by table, etc in the same format.

I ran into this error recently when testing Accumulo w/ k8s. It's a classpath issue where the Jetty jar from the Hadoop distro is being picked up first.

So, when using `accumulo-cluster` on `localhost`, `accumulo-env.sh` ends up getting called twice because we don't `ssh` to `localhost`. I'm not quite sure why the classpath being duplicated causes this issue.

Could the desired num tservers and sservers per host be placed in the `cluster.yaml` file instead of `accumulo-env.sh`?  Not completely sure how this would be done, so not sure if its possible.  If this could be done it then there is one file that a user needs to modify to change the behavior of the accumulo-cluster script instead of two.
